text.p: Australia's biggest ginner and marketer of cotton, Queensland Cotton Holdings Ltd, expects to have up to 90 percent of its next season's planting comprising new pest-resistent transgenic cotton seed, the group's chief executive, Richard Haire said on Tuesday.
"About 10 percent of our 1997 crop will be transgenic but next season up to 90 percent of our crop will comprise transgenic seed," Haire told Reuters in an interview.

The new crop seed will go a long way towards solving the industry's long-standing problems of having to spray crops to combat cotton moth pest, a practice which has alienated many farmers who are adjacent to cotton fields.
"The cotton industry in Australia has also been worried about the problem for many years as well as farmers," Haire said.
He said the 1997 season would see record Australian production of between 2.4 million and 2.5 million bales, compared with last year's national production of 1.9 million.

The major increase was expected to come from New South Wales because of abundant water supply which would offset flat Queensland production where the water supply has been "pretty volatile," Haire said.
"I'm pretty confident we have the marketing system which can successfully sell this season's record production," Haire said.
This was despite a world outlook for cotton which was currently looking a bit soft, he said.
"Consumption of cotton is not growing, mainly because of the high prices seen over the last two seasons. There is buyer resistance out there," Haire said.
"China production is down a bit and the United States market is mixed with exports down," he said.
However global demand for cotton would remain strong because of the fibre's premier position in manufacturing, Haire said.
Meanwhile, Queensland Cotton was continuing to look for new markets, having already expanded in Asia, particularly Indonesia and Malaysia, Haire said.
The group was also on the lookout for acquisition opportunities despite this year's failed merger attempt by Queensland Cotton and Namoi Cotton Co-operative.
There was still potential for rationalisation and expansion in the Australian cotton industry, Haire said.
Queensland Cotton was also looking at overseas acquisition opportunities, he said.
"We are always interested. Overseas acquisitions are always an option for us in growing the business, but currently it's only an option," Haire said.
Queensland Cotton reported a net profit of A$8.03 million for the year to February 29, up from A$6.28 million a year earlier.
For the six months to August 31, net profit was A$10.55 million on sales of A$268.31 million.
Sales for the full year to February were A$281.52 million.
